Dear Ms.Carey:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109 Program statement.
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents’ needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth self-harms and the most recent incident was yesterday. It is
believed youth used a bottle opener to cut herself yesterday
because staff were teasing her. It is unknown if youth has injuries.
Some of the youth at the facility are using marijuana however it is
unknown who is supplying the drugs. Youth does not feel safe at
the facility due to past incidents involving past youth. In the past,
a youth was playing with fire. Some youths are also touching
youth on her butt and chest. Staff have attempted to intervene,
but the youth continue to sexually abuse youth.
Investigation Phone messages were left with Complainant on October 25
and November 2, 2023, with no return call.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on October
25, 2023, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Staff 1 described
Youth A having a history of self-harming behavior. Staff 1 stated a
while ago Youth A got Tylenol at school and took a bunch of pills
and recently at the house Youth A took a can good item that had a
pull off top and hid it in her room. Staff 1 reported she was not
working when the incident occurred, but she heard about it from
staff. Staff 1 reported forks have been taken out of the kitchen
because Youth A was using them to try and cut herself. Staff 1
stated Youth A has a safety plan in place where Youth A must be
monitored all the time, Youth A’s bedroom door has to be open,
and Youth A is not allowed to have any sharp objects. Staff 1
2

denied ever hearing any staff tease Youth A about her cutting or
just in general teasing Youth A.
Staff 1 reported hearing youth talk about using marijuana while
they are at school. Staff 1 denied ever seeing youth use
marijuana while at the house or staff giving youth marijuana. Staff
1 stated the youth, and their belongings are searched upon
entering the house and staff also do room searches.
Staff 1 described a previous youth, Youth E, using the stove top to
try and catch something on fire. Staff 1 stated it was maybe one
month ago and it occurred twice. Staff 1 reported law
enforcement was contacted, and the other youth were taken
outside away from the situation and to keep them safe. Staff 1
stated she was working one of the times but not the second time
the incident took place.
Staff 1 denied ever seeing any youths inappropriately touch Youth
A. Staff 1 stated Youth A has never said anything to Staff 1 about
any of the youth touching her.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on
October 25, 2023, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Youth
A described being on suicide watch and staff always having eyes
on her and following her around since she cut herself. Youth A
reported staff took away the forks a while ago because Youth A
was using them to self-harm. Youth A reported she grabbed a
can good item that had a pull off top from the pantry while the staff
member was in the office. Youth A could not recall what staff was
working. Youth A stated she hid the can in her room and used the
lid to cut herself two days later. Youth A was not sure if she was
on “suicide watch” prior to this incident. Youth A denied any staff
ever teasing her. Youth A stated sometimes she feels staff
invalidate her feelings. Youth A reported Staff 4 has told Youth A,
“don’t go cutting yourself and telling me you just had to do it.”
Youth A reported youth get marijuana at school and recently
Youth D just got suspended for using a dab pen at school. Youth
A denied ever seeing youth use marijuana while at the house or
staff giving youth marijuana. Youth A reported staff always check
youths’ backpacks, sometimes shoes, and pockets to search for
anything the youth are not supposed to have. Youth A stated the
bedrooms also get searched by staff.
Youth A described a former youth, Youth E, trying to set the house
on fire two different times. Youth A stated the first time Youth E
3

was escalated and tried putting a paper towel on the stove top to
catch it on fire. Youth A reported staff tried to stop Youth E and
calm Youth E down, but she would not listen or change her
behavior. Youth A stated staff took all the youth outside and
called the police. Youth A reported she could not recall the details
of the second time.
Youth A stated she feels safe at the house and feels like she is
starting to fit in at school. Youth A reported Youth D makes
threats and sometimes the staff redirect Youth D and sometimes
staff do not redirect. Youth A stated Youth D talks about Youth
A’s butt and touched Youth A’s butt and breasts in front of staff.
Youth A stated staff redirected Youth D and talked to both Youth A
and Youth D.
Youth B was interviewed face to face at the facility on
October 25, 2023, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Youth
B reported liking it at the facility, feeling safe and getting along
with the staff. Youth B reported there is one staff maybe two staff
depending on the day, that work in the evenings and on
weekends. Youth B stated staff sit in the kitchen and always have
an eye on the youth. Youth B denied ever hearing a staff member
hurtfully tease a youth. Youth B stated Staff 4 will sometimes use
sarcasm, but you can always tell she is kidding or joking. Youth B
described staff redirecting youth, stepping in or giving
consequences if youth say or do something to another youth they
should not do. Youth B stated a former youth, Youth E, punched
another youth and went “crazy”. Youth B stated youths went to
their rooms to get away from Youth E while staff tried to
deescalate Youth E.
Youth B stated youth get edibles at school and get high. Youth B
reported Youth D was high at school and got suspended. Youth B
stated staff always search the youths’ bag and bedrooms if staff
suspect youth are hiding something. Youth B denied ever seeing
youth use marijuana while at the house or staff giving youth
marijuana.
Youth C was interviewed face to face at the facility on
October 25, 2023, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Youth
C stated it was “okay” at the facility, but she does not like the staff.
Youth C did not provide any reason for not liking staff. Youth C
reported she “sometimes feels safe.” Youth C described youth
fight and staff will try and break it up or tell youth to go to their
rooms. Youth C denied ever hearing staff tease any youth.
4

Youth C reported she did not know about drugs or marijuana.
Youth C stated it was not her business. Youth C reported staff
check youths’ bags when they return to the house or check the
bedrooms if youth are being sneaking.Youth C stated she was
done talking about requested to leave the room.
Youth D refused to talk with DHHS Worker and I on October
25, 2023.
Staff 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on October
25, 2023, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Staff 2 stated
she has been off for an extended period. Staff 2 reported she is
aware Youth A is currently on a safety plan and there has been
discussion that Staff 2 will start doing a 1:1 with Youth A due to
Youth A’s self-harming. Staff 2 denied ever hearing any staff
member tease a youth.
Staff 2 denied youth getting marijuana at the house. Staff 2
reported youths’ bags are always checked upon arrival at the
facility. Staff 2 stated bedrooms are also checked.
Staff 2 described being outside with the youths when she
witnessed Youth D grab Youth A’s “behind.” Staff 2 stated this
was the first time she ever witnessed any inappropriate touch.
Staff 2 reported she addressed the behavior with Youth D,
completed an incident report and documented the incident.
Staff 3 was interviewed face to face at the facility on October
25, 2023, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Staff 3 reported
Youth A is currently on a safety plan for self-harming, so staff
must monitor Youth A at all times. Staff 3 stated all the staff get
emails with updates to any safety plan and are verbally told about
the plans by Case Manager. Staff 3 stated the safety plans are
also documented in the summary sheets. Staff 3 denied ever
hearing any staff member tease a youth.
Staff 3 reported hearing Youth C and Youth D talk about vaping at
school. Staff 3 stated staff regularly search youths’ bedrooms and
bags when youth return from any outing. Staff 3 denied youth
getting marijuana at the house or seeing any youth use marijuana
while at the house.
Staff 3 reported she heard about Youth E trying to set clothes on
fire and destroying the house. Staff 3 stated she was not working
the day the incident took place. Staff 3 described when youth
become escalated staff verbally work to deescalate the youth,
5

separate the other youth in the house and if needed call Director
for support.
Staff 3 denied seeing any youth touch Youth A but stated she read
about an incident in the logbook. Staff 3 reported in the past
youth have stated they like one another so staff monitor those
youth closely and “stay ahead of any issues.”
Case Manager was interviewed face to face at the facility on
October 25, 2023, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Case
Manager stated Youth A is on a safety plan for the most recent
issue of cutting with a can top. Case Manager reported the safety
plan is in the process of being updated to have Staff 2 be an
additional staff on shift and work directly with Youth A. Case
Manager denied every hearing any staff tease a youth. Case
Manager stated Youth A has never come to her with concerns
regarding any staff member.
Case Manager denied youths getting marijuana at the house.
Case Manager stated it has been an issue with the youth’s getting
marijuana at school and Youth D is currently suspended from
school. Case Manager reported youth bags and belongings are
searched when they return from school or any outing. Case
Manager stated the youths’ bedrooms are searched as well.
Case Manager reported a previous youth, Youth E, did attempt to
light items on fire from the stove top. Case Manager stated staff
intervened, the other youth were moved away from the incident
and law enforcement, along with the Director, were contacted.
Case Manager reported she has never seen any youth touch
Youth A. Case Manager reported Youth A told her Youth C and
Youth D were touching Youth A’s butt, so Case Manager had a
conversation with all the youths. Case Manager reported Youth A
and Youth D used to share a bedroom but now the youths have
separate bedrooms.
Staff 4 was interviewed face to face at the facility on October
25, 2023, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Staff 4 denied
ever hearing any staff tease any youth or make comments to
Youth A about self-harming. Staff 4 reported Youth A got some
pills at school one time and took them but there had not been any
incidents of self-harm recently at the house until a few days ago.
Staff 4 reported Youth A is now on a safety where Youth A has to
be with staff at all times and is not allowed any sharp objects.
6

Staff 4 stated youth have gotten edibles and vapes while at
school. Staff 4 denied any youth getting marijuana from staff at the
house. Staff 4 described youths’ bags and self being searched
when coming back to the house after being gone.
Staff 4 described being at the house for one of the incidents when
Youth E tried to use the stove top to catch a pair of pants on fire.
Staff 4 stated she verbally redirected Youth E, got the other youth
away from Youth E and contacted law enforcement. Staff 4
reported Youth E was removed from the house by law
enforcement and did not return.
Staff 4 denied ever seeing any youth inappropriately touch Youth
A or Youth A telling Staff 4 about being touched. Staff 4 stated
staff “nip that in the bud” if anything is taking place with the
youths.
Staff 5 was interviewed face to face at the facility on October
25, 2023, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Staff 5 denied
ever hearing any staff member tease Youth A or say anything to
Youth A about self-harming. Staff 5 reported Youth A has talked
to her about her feelings and her previous self-harming. Staff 5
stated Youth A is now on a safety plan to be monitored at all
times, Youth A cannot have her bedroom door closed at night, has
to have more frequent room searches and is not allowed any
sharp objects. Staff 5 stated most of the time she is the only staff
member with the four youths in the evening so it can be difficult to
manage all the behaviors. Staff 5 reported she can always call
Director for support and if the youths’ really get escalated law
enforcement is contacted.
Staff 5 denied being aware of any youth using marijuana at the
house or getting marijuana from any staff member. Staff 5 stated
youths will get edibles, mushrooms or vapes at school and have
been suspended. Staff 5 reported the youths’ bags are always
searched along with their bedrooms.
Staff 5 described two incidents where Youth E attempted to use
the stove top to catch items on fire. Staff 5 stated verbal de-
escalation was used, Youth E continued to escalate, other youths
went to their rooms to separate them from Youth E’s behaviors
and law enforcement was contacted.
Staff 5 denied ever seeing any youths inappropriately touch Youth
A. Staff 5 stated she read about an incident where Youth D
touched Youth A’s butt. Staff 5 reported youths would be
7

redirected if that occurred, and an incident report would be
completed.
DHHS Worker has no findings in the investigation.
Documents Reviewed:
• Safety Plan for Youth A, no date: Youth A will remain in den
during daytime hours being closely monitored by staff,
checked per program protocol when returning from outdoor
activities, bedroom door will be slightly opened during
bedtime hours with increased bed checks, follow
recommended treatment plan at New Oakland by attending
daily to receive the necessary assistance and verbalize
issues/concerns with staff and/or DHHS Foster Care
Specialist.
• Updated Safety Plan for Youth A, no date, added to the
plan listed above was: Monitored with one-on-one support
in the afternoon by a Beverly House staff, and Youth A’s
housemate was removed from shared bedroom, Youth A is
in a bedroom alone.
• Critical and Recordable Consumer Incident Report for
Youth A dated 10/20/23: Youth A had mental melt down at
school, told teacher she had cut her left arm and right leg.
Youth A was seen by school nurse who called Youth A’s
worker and CPS. CPS came to facility and explained
Youth A needed to have psychiatric evaluation. Youth A
was taken to Beaumont Annapolis Hospital and kept over
night for observation and evaluation.
• After Visit Summary Report from Beaumont for Youth A
dated 10/20/23: Reason for visit was for laceration;
diagnosis with depression, unspecified depression type.
• Medical Treatment Report for Youth A dated 10/21/23:
Evaluation completed by clinical social worker and Youth A
cleared to return home. Youth A does not meet criteria for
inpatient mental health hospitalization at this time.
• Unusual Incident Report for Youth D dated 10/22/23
completed by Staff 2: Youth D was observed grabbing
Youth A’s “behind.” Staff 2 spoke with Youth D regarding
her behavior explaining it was inappropriate and against
program rules.
• Spectrum Child & Family Services Youth Residential
Services Programs Self Harm and Suicide Procedures:
Safety interventions are close monitoring, increased
random bed checks, bedroom doors left open,
room/environment is modified by removing objects that
pose a risk and interventions may be modified.
8

• Spectrum Child & Family Services Youth Residential
Services Programs Behavior Management Policy and
Procedures: “It is the policy of the Youth Residential
Service Programs to not use corporal punishment or
physical restraint. Youth Residential Services stress the
importance of attempting to employ verbal de-escalation as
a first response to physically aggressive behavior. Staff will
utilize approved crisis prevention techniques, i.e.,
prevention, de-escalation techniques, escorting, and non-
violent responses to assaultive behavior, which includes a
trauma-informed approach. If such efforts are ineffective
local law enforcement is contacted.”
Analysis The facility is found in compliance as staff and youth reported
through interviews, staff members are not teasing Youth A about
self-harming. Staff took appropriate measures implementing a
safety plan for Youth A’s self-harming incident. Staff 2 did witness
Youth D touch Youth A’s butt and appropriately addressed the
behavior and completed an incident report. Youths interviewed
reported staff verbally intervening or separate youth to keep
everyone safe. Staff members and youths deny youth getting
marijuana at the facility. It was reported youths are getting edibles
and vape pens at school.
Technical Assistance:
It was recommended the facility date safety plans to show when
the plan is effective and when the plan will be discontinued or was
updated. The current safety plans for Youth A were not dated
making it unclear as to what plan was in place during what specific
dates.
It is recommended the facility their admission criteria and staff
ratio. The facility is a hands-free facility and many times only one
staff is working the evening and weekend shifts which can make it
difficult for the one staff to manage all the youths behaviors.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4150 Incident reporting.
Section (4) When a resident’s behavior results in contact with law
Description enforcement, the incident shall be reported to the parent/legal
guardian, responsible referring agency, and the licensing authority
as soon as possible, but not more than 24 hours after the incident.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
9

Allegation The facility did not notify the licensing authority that law
enforcement was at the facility for a youth's behaviors on
09/04/23, 09/05/23 and 09/20/23.
Investigation Consultant was contacted via email on November 3, 2023.
Consultant denied being aware law enforcement was at the facility
due to youths’ behaviors.
Case Manager was contacted via email on November 3, 2023.
Case Manager reported Consultant was not notified of law
enforcement being at the facility.
Documents Reviewed:
• Critical and Recordable Consumer Incident Report for
Youth E dated 09/04/23: Law enforcement contacted due to
Youth E’s attempt to self-harm and set clothes on fire.
• Critical and Recordable Consumer Incident Report for
Youth D dated 09/05/23: Law enforcement contacted due
to Youth D becoming belligerent and combative with
another youth.
• Critical and Recordable Consumer Incident Report for
Youth E dated 09/20/23: Law enforcement contacted due to
Youth E physically assaulting other youth, deploying the fire
extinguisher, and destruction of property. Youth E was
taken into police custody for her behavior.
Analysis The facility is found in noncompliance as DCWL, the licensing
authority, was not notified law enforcement.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4150 Incident reporting.
Section (3) If an institution determines that a youth is absent without legal
Description permission, then the institution shall immediately report the
information to law enforcement, the parent/ legal guardian or next
of kin, the licensing authority, and the referring agency.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation The facility failed to report Youth B AWOL.
Investigation Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on
October 25, 2023, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Youth
A reported about two weeks ago Youth B jumped out the window
and walked to a friend’s house because Youth D was threatening
to kill everyone in the house. Youth A stated Staff 5 did not
contact police. Youth A could not recall how long Youth B was
gone, only that it was “awhile.” Youth A stated Staff 5 called
Youth B on Youth B’s phone and told Youth B she needed to
return to the house.
10

Case Manager was interviewed face to face at the facility on
October 25, 2023, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Case
Manager stated she was not working the night Youth B went out
the window and ran to a friend’s house, but Case Manager heard
about the incident. Case Manager reported Youth B was not
reported as AWOL, no report was filed, and an incident report was
not completed but Case Manager would have considered Youth B
AWOL and reported the incident.
Staff 5 was interviewed face to face at the facility on October
25, 2023, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Staff 5 described
Youth B sneaking out the window the night Youth D became
escalated and was threatening the youths in the house. Staff 5
stated Youth B and Youth C went to their room, they shared a
room at the time, when Youth D was escalated. Staff 5 reported
when she went to check on Youth B and Youth C, Youth C told
Staff 5, Youth B went out the window and left the house. Staff 5
stated she called Youth B on Youth B’s phone and told her she
needed to return to the house. Staff 5 described Youth B leaving
without permission, not knowing where Youth B was but not
reporting or writing Youth B up as AWOL. Staff 5 stated she
believed Youth B was at a friend’s house and was gone for about
20 minutes. Staff 5 reported viewing Youth B as, “being gone
without permission rather than AWOL.”
Documents Reviewed:
• Spectrum Child & Family Services Youth Residential
Services State of Michigan DHHS AWOLP Requirements:
“In accordance with State of Michigan Department of
Human Services requirements on youth that are absent
without legal permission (AWOLP), the following procedure
must be followed by Youth Residential Services Programs.
Staff will confirm with the Resident Supervisor that
notification of all required parties occurred immediately and
documented in the communication log with the specific
time.”
Analysis The facility is found in noncompliance as Youth B was not
reported AWOL and no incident report was completed. Staff 5
described Youth B being gone for about 20 minutes, not knowing
Youth B’s exact location, Youth B leaving without permission, but
not reporting Youth B as AWOL or following agency policy when a
youth AWOLs.
Conclusion Violation Established
11

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
